questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves are affected in cavernous sinus syndrome?
questions.solution:
The cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI are affected by cavernous sinus syndrome.

The cavernous sinus syndrome is a condition caused by any pathology involving the cavernous sinus. The oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV) and trigeminal (V) nerves pass in relation to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. The abducent (VI) nerve passes through the cavernous sinus.

Patients with this condition usually present with the following features:

  • Orbital or facial pain
  • Orbital swelling and chemosis due to occlusion of the ophthalmic veins
  • Fever
  • Oculomotor neuropathy (III, IV, and VI)
  • Trigeminal neuropathy (V)

Causes of cavernous sinus syndrome include:

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis - most common
  • Carotid artery aneurysm
  • Carotid-cavernous fistula
  • Tumors such as meningioma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding trigeminal neuralgia?

choices.text: The region of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve is always spared
The pain usually last for a few hours
The condition is also known as tic douloureux
It is more common in men

questions.solution:
Tic douloureux is another term for trigeminal neuralgia.

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by frequent paroxysms of severe pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin. It is sometimes seen in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

Middle-aged and elderly females are primarily affected. The pain usually lasts for a short time (seconds to minutes) but be may intense enough that the patient winces, hence the term 'tic'.

A characteristic feature is the presence of trigger zones, typically on the face, lips, or tongue. Patients usually report excruciating pain during activities such as washing the face or brushing the teeth. However, no signs of sensory loss can be demonstrated.

questions.text: The high frequency of trigeminal neuralgia in patients with multiple sclerosis is mainly attributed to the involvement of ______.

choices.text: Oligodendrocyte-derived myelin covering the beginning of the nerve
Oligodendrocyte-derived myelin covering the terminal part of the nerve
Schwann cell–derived myelin sheath covering the beginning of the nerve
Schwann cell–derived myelin sheath covering the terminal part of the nerve

questions.solution:
The high frequency of trigeminal neuralgia in patients with multiple sclerosis occurs due to the involvement of oligodendrocyte-derived myelin covering the beginning of the nerve.

Multiple sclerosis is a disorder of oligodendrocyte myelin. It should be ruled out when trigeminal neuralgia is bilateral or develops in a young adult. In such cases, the cause is a demyelinating plaque near the root entry zone of the fifth cranial nerve in the pons. In these patients, a facial sensory loss is also often found in association.

questions.text: In patients with trigeminal neuralgia, the nerve is most commonly compressed by ______.
questions.solution:
The superior cerebellar artery most often compresses the trigeminal nerve as it emerges from the brainstem. This causes lancinating pain in the distribution of the nerve which is known as trigeminal neuralgia.

Though trigeminal neuralgia can be diagnosed by the clinical features, MRI is recommended to define the underlying cause. In cases refractory to medical management, it also helps to plan for surgical decompression.

questions.text: A food vlogger presents with complaints of episodes of piercing electric-shock like pain on the left side of her face. The episodes are triggered by chewing food and last for a few minutes. She is further distressed as it interferes with her work. She has tried over the counter analgesics to no avail. What is the drug of choice for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia and the drug of choice is carbamazepine.

Oxcarbazepine is an alternative to carbamazepine that has less bone marrow toxicity and is equally efficacious.

Other drugs used are lamotrigine, gabapentin and baclofen.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Bell's palsy?

choices.text: MRI shows enhancement of geniculate ganglion

questions.solution:
Maximal weakness occurs within 48 hours as a rule in Bells' palsy.

Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion of the facial nerve.

Clinical presentation of Bell’s palsy:

  • Pain behind the ear (may precede paralysis and last for 1-2 days)
  • Bell's phenomenon
  • Asymmetrical face
  • Hyperacusis (due to stapedial paralysis)
  • Loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani).

MRI may reveal swelling and uniform enhancement of the geniculate ganglion and facial nerve.

Approximately 80% of patients recover within a few weeks or months. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favorable prognostic sign. Recurrence may be seen in some cases.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is most commonly implicated in Bell’s palsy?
questions.solution:
Herpes simplex virus is most commonly implicated in causing Bell’s palsy.

Varicella-zoster virus is the second most common cause.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Bell’s phenomenon?

choices.text: Eyeballs roll upwards on attempting to open the eyes
Eyeballs roll downwards on attempting to close the eyes
It is a normal phenomenon evident in facial paralysis
It is an abnormal phenomenon evident in facial paralysis

questions.solution:
Bell’s phenomenon refers to a normal phenomenon that becomes evident in facial paralysis. The eyeballs roll up and outwards on attempting to close the eyes.

It is also known as the palpebral oculogyric reflex. It is a normal protective reflex resulting in the elevation of globes while blinking to protect the eyes from injury. It also serves to provide a wiper blade-like cleansing function of the cornea by the eyelid.

However, it occurs behind the closed eyelids in healthy individuals. It becomes noticeable in Bell's palsy as the eyelids fail to close completely.

questions.text: On returning from work, a man noticed that his mother had developed mild right-sided facial drooping. Believing it to be due to a stroke, he immediately took her to the hospital. After extensive evaluation, the doctor ruled out stroke and diagnosed her with Bell's palsy. Which of the following would not be a part of the management of her condition?

choices.text: Paper tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep
Prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days

questions.solution:
Acyclovir may be considered as add-on therapy for patients with severe Bell's palsy as 400mg five times daily for 10 days. Monotherapy is not recommended.

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. Randomized trials found no added benefit of the antiviral agents valacyclovir and acyclovir when compared to glucocorticoids alone.

The use of paper tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep prevents corneal drying.

For patients with permanent paralysis, cosmetic surgical procedures have been used to restore a relatively symmetric appearance to the face.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with facial weakness and pain for the past 2 days. The following signs are seen on examination. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The features are suggestive of lower motor neuron (LMN) type of facial palsy.

In the image, the absence of wrinkling over the right side of the forehead and incomplete closure of the right eyelid is characteristic of LMN type of facial palsy. 

In upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, the upper part of the face is spared due to bilateral UMN innervation. 

Features of facial nerve palsy:

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy of facial muscles Absent Present

Note: Deviation of the angle of mouth should not be confused with drooping of the angle of mouth. Deviation of the angle of the mouth occurs on the normal side due to the action of unaffected facial muscles, while drooping occurs on the affected side.

questions.text:
Identify the correct type of facial nerve palsy in the following patients based on their clinical features:

Patient 1 - Deviation of angle of mouth to left, eyelids completely closed and wrinkling of the forehead. 

Patient 2 - Deviation of angle of mouth to left, the right eyelid remains partially open, and no wrinkling of the forehead.
questions.solution:
Patient 1 has left UMN facial nerve palsy and patient 2 has right LMN facial nerve palsy.

In an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, wrinkling on the forehead and eyelid closure remains intact. In this lesion, the contralateral side of the face is affected. The first-order neurons from the left cerebral hemisphere cross over (left to right) at the cortical level and relay in the right facial nerve nucleus in the pons. From here the second-order neurons (right facial nerve) descend and supply the right side of the face. 

Hence, a left UMN lesion causes paralysis of the lower half of the face on the right side. In facial palsy, the angle of the mouth deviates towards the normal side. In this patient, since the mouth deviates towards the left, the right facial nerve is affected. 

In lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions, there is an absence of wrinkling on the forehead and incomplete closure of the eyelid on the ipsilateral side of the face.

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy Absent Present

questions.text: During the neurological examination of a patient, you note that he has bilateral lower motor neuron palsy of the facial nerve. Which of the following is least likely to cause this?
questions.solution:
Diabetes is associated with unilateral LMN palsy.

questions.text: You are evaluating a woman with unilateral facial weakness. However, you notice forehead wrinkling is intact. On examination, which of the following findings would you not expect?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion of the facial nerve in which the emotional response is affected. Patients with UMN lesions of the facial nerve have emotional incontinence i.e. involuntary, uncontrollable laughter, or crying with a paradoxical deficit of facial expression.

Normally cerebellum modulates motor outputs in response to sensory inputs. UMN facial palsy (type of pseudobulbar palsy) is associated with disruption of cortico-ponto-cerebellar pathways leading to loss of cerebellar modulation resulting in:

  • Emotional dysmetria (difficulty in fine-tuning emotional responses)
  • Emotional disinhibition (excessive emotional output)

Difference between UMN and LMN facial palsy:

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy Absent Present

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about facial synkinesis?

choices.text: Refers to simultaneous bilateral facial nerve palsy
Refers to facial nerve palsy associated with trigeminal neuralgia
Occurs due to anomalous regeneration of the facial nerve fibers
Loss of emotional response is seen in this condition

questions.solution:
Facial synkinesis occurs due to anomalous regeneration of facial nerve fibers.

Following facial nerve injury , the recovering nerve fibers may aberrantly regenerate and supply other muscles. This results in involuntary muscular movements in the face during voluntary facial movements.

Some examples include:

  • Retraction of the mouth on closure of the eyelids:
    • Seen when fibers originally connected with the orbicularis oculi aberrantly innervate the orbicularis oris
  • 'Crocodile tears' also known as Bogorad syndrome:
    • It refers to anomalous tearing occurring with activity of the facial muscles, such as eating.
    • Due to aberrant innervation of the lacrimal gland.

Note: Frey's syndrome is an aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and the great auricular nerve, resulting in gustatory sweating.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding hemifacial spasm?

choices.text: The contractions are painful and irregular
It is a complication of Bell's palsy
Local injection of botulinum toxin is effective

questions.solution:
Hemifacial spasms are painless irregular contractions occurring on one side of the face.

They commonly occur as sequelae to Bell's palsy. It can also be seen in irritative lesions of the facial nerve such as acoustic neuroma and basilar aneurysm.

Treatment is with carbamazepine or gabapentin. In resistant cases, baclofen may be tried. Local injection of botulinum toxin and surgical decompression are alternative options.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of Melkerrson-Rosenthal syndrome?
  1. Recurrent facial nerve palsy
  2. Congenital facial weakness
  3. Facial edema
  4. Plication of tongue
  5. Vesicular rash in auditory canal
questions.solution:
Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is a rare disease characterised by the following triad:

  • Recurrent facial nerve palsy
  • Facial edema (particularly labial)
  • Plication of tongue or fissured tongue

Facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna is seen in Ramsay-Hunt syndrome. It occurs due to herpes zoster infection and is also called herpes zoster oticus.

Congenital facial weakness combined with abnormal ocular abduction is seen in Moebius syndrome. Patients may present with bilateral concurrent facial nerve paralysis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with complaints of sudden stabs of pain in the throat on yawning. Each episode only lasted for a few seconds and was exacerbated on trying to clear the throat. Which of the following findings can you see on examination?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of glossopharyngeal neuralgia which is associated with cardiac symptoms such as bradycardia, asystole, hypotension, and fainting. 

It involves the glossopharyngeal (IX) and sometimes portions of the vagus (X) nerve. The condition resembles trigeminal neuralgia but is less common. There is no demonstrable sensory or motor deficit.

It can result from vascular compression, multiple sclerosis or tumors. 

The drug of choice is carbamazepine. If unsuccessful, surgical procedures are indicated:

  • Microvascular decompression (if vascular compression is evident)
  • Rhizotomy of glossopharyngeal and vagal fibers in the jugular bulb
